title: January 2021 Market Commentary: YOTO (You Only Trade Once)
text: Global equity markets continued their sharp advance throughout most of January as post-pandemic reflationary optimism pervaded investor risk appetite, only to pull back sharply at the end of January. The selling pressure was partly due to ‘technical' selling pressures brought on by trade battles between institutional hedge funds and retail investors.

title: Fed's George: Too Soon to Discuss Tapering Bond Buying
text: Feb.04 -- Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City President Esther George discusses the state of the U.S. economy amid the coronavirus pandemic and the central bank's policy. George says the Fed is still "far away" from achieving its goals and it is premature to start a debate on scaling back its massive bond-buying program.

title: Yellen meets with regulators over GameStop volatility, vows to protect investors
text: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen convened a meeting with the nation's top regulators Thursday, who are continuing to review whether recent volatility in popular "meme stocks," and brokers response to it, "are consistent with investor protection and fair and efficient markets," according to a Treasury Department statement.

text: A U. S. court upheld former president Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs on foreign steel in a decision issued Thursday, raising questions over whether the Biden administration would keep in place policies that helped spark a global trade war in 2018.

title: Nasdaq Scores All-Time High, Helped By Bullish Earnings Reports
text: The Nasdaq composite and Russell 2000 hit all-time highs Thursday, helped by a barrage of strong earnings reports. title: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records after economic data, upbeat earnings
text: Stocks ended higher Thursday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite closing at records as investors appeared to cheer economic data and a continued run of upbeat corporate earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose around 332 points, or 1.1%, to close near 31,056, according to preliminary figures.

title: S&P 500 and Nasdaq hit records on positive labor-market data
text: US equities gained on Thursday as declining COVID-19 case counts and jobless claims fueled a fourth straight day of market gains. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite closed at record highs, lifted by rallying tech and bank stocks. The materials sector was the only one of 11 groups in the S&P 500 to decline through the session.

title: The stock market could jump 20% from current levels as buy-the-dip mentality continues, JPMorgan says
text: Conditioned to "buy-the-dip" in stocks for more than a decade, investors continue to do just that, illustrated by the swift rebound from last week's 3% decline in the S&P 500. They should stick with that mentality going forward as the stock market is set to jump 20% from current levels, JPMorgan said in a note on Thursday.

title: International Equities Enter 2021 With Momentum

title: Looking For Yield? Look To REITs
text: Investors seeking a predictable source of income should consider a dividend investing strategy. Dividend payments are made to shareholders when a publicly traded company earns a profit and decides to allocate some of these funds to their shareholders.

title: A Most Unusual Recession - A Mostly Typical (If Protracted) Recovery
text: The initial downturn was unusually swift and deep, as was the initial recovery, but the recovery path is reverting to more typical patterns as the expansion has lost momentum. New forecasts from the Congressional Budget Office predict that GDP will return to its pre-pandemic peak by this summer, though jobs won't regain their former peak for three more years.

title: Economic Report: The U.S. likely added jobs in January, but here's why an increase could be misleading
text: The U.S. economy might have added jobs in January after a decline in employment at the end of 2020, but don't be fooled. The labor market is still struggling to recover from the winter coronavirus onslaught.

title: Dow Earnings Headlines Slow Week Ahead
text: The second week of February is relatively slow in terms of economic data, but there are still plenty of earnings reports for investors to sift through, including a few blue chips as well as a couple buzz-worthy start-ups.

title: The Yield Curve Is the Steepest It Has Been in Years. Here's What That Means for Investors.
text: Long-term Treasury yields have been rising much faster than shorter-term yields, a sign that investors are betting on further acceleration in the U.S.'s economic recovery. Bank stocks should benefit, and a repeat "taper tantrum" is unlikely.

title: Technical Update: Stock Indices Remain Bullish
text: The uptrends in the major U.S. stock market indices remain firmly intact. The recent pullback in the S&P 500 Index and Nasdaq Composite held at an important price support zone, and I see the start of another leg higher for these stock market indices.

title: Looking for a Correction? It Might Have Already Happened.
text: The S&P 500 fell 3.7% between the closes of Jan. 25 and Jan. 29, during the recent short squeeze. The minute it cooled, stocks popped, trading on fundamentals and sending the S&P 500 back to its pre-selloff level.

title: US economy faces 'tough months ahead' before staging a strong recovery, Treasury Secretary Yellen says
text: The US economy will struggle for at least a few more months before falling COVID-19 cases and stimulus can drive a full recovery, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said Thursday. In her first television interview since being confirmed last week, Yellen emphasized the importance of using stimulus to bridge the final months of the virus-induced slump.

title: Ex-Fed official says trading frenzy a ‘concern,' but doubts likelihood of regulatory action
text: Former Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Dennis Lockhart reveals his expectations for Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's meeting with regulators on the short-selling frenzy.

title: It's Halftime for Earnings, but It Hasn't Been a Blowout
text: Roughly 260 out of 500 companies in the S&P 500 have reported year-end 2020 numbers. Things are going pretty well, but investors appear to want more.

title: Monthly Paid Dividend Stocks And Funds Find Love In February
text: Imagine a stock or fund that paid out its dividends once a month. Instead of quarterly, semi-annually or (ugh) annually, your anticipatory angst waiting for your money is reduced by 300% or more. February's U.S. exchange-traded monthly paid (MoPay) dividends, upsides, and net gains include: 1. Stocks by yield (73); 2. Stocks by price upside (30); 3. Closed-End-Investments, Exchange-Traded-Funds & Notes (CEICs/ETFs/ETNs) by yield >7.80% (80).

title: Don't Fear Inflation, Bond Bull Market Isn't Over, GSAM's Swell Says
text: Feb.04 -- Mike Swell, co-head of global fixed income portfolio management at Goldman Sachs Asset Management, explains the need for stimulus despite improving U.S. economic data and why investors shouldn't expect runaway inflation. He speaks on "Bloomberg Markets.

title: A historic decline in volatility sets the stock market up for more gains ahead, Fundstrat's Tom Lee says
text: The stock market's fear gauge — or the Cboe Volatility index, also known as the VIX — has staged a historic decline over the past three days, falling a record 39%. According to Fundstrat's Tom Lee, that's a signal that the stock market has more room to the upside over the next few months, according to a Wednesday note.

title: Dow Theory Has Equities On Breakdown Watch
text: Over 100 years ago, Charles Dow wrote articles for Barron's that formed the basis for much of the technical analysis toolkit used today. Dow's work involved relating two key indexes- the Dow Industrials and the Dow Railroads- to determine the trajectory of the stock market and its implications for broader economic conditions.

title: Stocks Rise Again: Leaders and Laggards Review
text: The major stock market indices are on the rise again in pre-market futures trading. Yesterday we saw stocks rise with some end-of-day selling.

title: Code red — here's what it means for the stock market now that company insiders are selling shares
text: The stock market is vulnerable to a decline because of overvaluation, while "reopening" and cyclical stocks have been overplayed.
